intro: Sanvitalia tragiifolia, commonly known as the Mexican firecracker, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its striking, tubular red or orange flowers that bloom in summer. The plant has slender, branching stems and small, opposite leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. It thrives in full sun and well-drained soil, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and containers. Its vibrant flowers attract pollinators such as bees and hummingbirds, contributing to its ecological value.
